titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the T. F. Gilroy Daly Papers
titlestmt.author: Barbara Heck, Carol King, and David Miller

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Thursday January 10, 2019 at 10:58

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: The papers consist of correspondence, continuing education course materials, legal pleadings, memoranda, newspaper clippings, photographs, reports, subject files, and writings that document T. F. Gilroy Daly's career as a United States District Court judge. The papers provide a comprehensive overview of Daly's career from his appointment in 1977 until his death in 1996. The materials regarding Daly's service as the chief judge of the United States District Court for the District of Connecticut from 1983 to 1988 are extensive and document the substantial administrative responsibilities of the position.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of the Estate of T. F. Gilroy Daly, 1996.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright has been transferred to Yale University for unpublished materials authored or otherwise produced by the creator(s) of this collection. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: T. F. Gilroy Daly Papers. (MS 1718). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Thomas Francis Gilroy Daly, known as T. F. Gilroy Daly, was born on February 25, 1931, in New York City. He received his B.A. from Georgetown University in 1952. Daly served in Korea in the U. S. Army Rangers from 1953 to 1955 and attained the rank of first lieutenant. After completion of military service, Daly went to Yale Law School where he obtained his J.D. in 1957 and received the John Fletcher Caskey Prize for outstanding performance in a moot court trial.

After graduation, Daly practiced law in Washington, D.C., for five years. He then served as an assistant United States attorney for the Southern District of New York from 1961 to 1964. Daly practiced law in Connecticut from 1964 to 1977. In addition to his practice, he held several positions in Connecticut government: deputy state attorney general from 1967 to 1971, special assistant to the state attorney general from 1971 to 1975, deputy state treasurer from 1975 to 1976, and state insurance commissioner from 1976 to 1977.

Daly gained prominence in the 1970s for his pivotal role in obtaining freedom for Peter Reilly. In 1974, Reilly, aged eighteen, was convicted of manslaughter in the stabbing death of his mother. The conviction was largely based upon Reilly's confession, which his supporters maintained was the product of police coercion. After his conviction, Reilly's supporters convinced Daly to enter the case and appeal the conviction. It was discovered that the prosecutor, now dead, had not disclosed exculpatory evidence to Reilly's attorney. After a six-week hearing, Reilly was released from prison and the charge was dismissed.

Daly was nominated by President Jimmy Carter to serve as a United States District Court judge for the District of Connecticut in 1977. He served on the Court until his death in 1996. He was chief judge of the District of Connecticut from 1983 to 1988.
T. F. Gilroy Daly died on July 11, 1996, and was survived by his wife, Stuart Stetson Daly, and their four children, Timothy, Loan, Matthew, and Anna.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers consist of correspondence, continuing education course materials, legal pleadings, memoranda, newspaper clippings, photographs, reports, subject files, and writings that document T. F. Gilroy Daly's career as a United States District Court judge. The papers provide a comprehensive overview of Daly's career from his appointment in 1977 until his death in 1996. The materials regarding Daly's service as the chief judge of the United States District Court for the District of Connecticut from 1983 to 1988 are extensive and document the substantial administrative responsibilities of the position.
There are no materials relating to the Peter Reilly court case.

The T. F. Gilroy Daly Papers were processed as a collaborative effort between Manuscripts and Archives and the Yale Law School to document the careers and accomplishments of Law School faculty and alumni.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged in two series: I. Judicial Agencies and Activities, 1966-1996. II. Professional Organizations and Topical Files, 1950-1996.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes correspondence, memoranda, newspaper clippings, photographs, reports and other materials created or collected by T. F. Gilroy Daly and relating to various judicial agencies, organizations, and individuals. The majority pertain to federal judicial activities, particularly from administrative agencies such as the Administrative Office of the United States Courts (AOUSC) and from individuals and departments within the Connecticut federal court system. Daly's original filing system, in which materials were filed by the name of the organization, office, or topic, has largely been retained.

Significant amounts of material document the response of the federal judiciary to crises involving class action suits, alternative dispute resolution methods, criminal sentencing, and increasing number of civil and criminal cases. Also illustrated in the Connecticut District Court files are the wide-ranging administrative responsibilities that Daly had, in addition to his regular caseload, when he served as chief district court judge between 1983 and 1988.

Correspondence with other district court judges and court officials is largely routine. Congressional correspondence is dominated by repeated requests for additional federal judges for Connecticut and responses by the judiciary to legislative proposals. General correspondence is also largely routine and includes notes and invitations to and from various judicial and political officeholders and letters from the public commenting upon Daly's decisions. Correspondence from prisoners generally includes requests for assistance in obtaining new hearings or trials, improved prison facilities, transfers to other locations, or relief from alleged abuse by prison staff. Also noteworthy are letters, newspaper clippings, and other items exchanged between Daly and his law clerks after the completion of their clerkships.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes correspondence, continuing education course materials, newspaper clippings, and other written materials from professional organizations that T. F. Gilroy Daly was a member of, or subject files that he created. Daly was an active member of several federal and state professional organizations and received information from others as a member of the judiciary. Arranged alphabetically by topic or organization name. The majority of the materials in this series relate to activities of the federal and Connecticut bar.

Topical files consist largely of articles, surveys, and course materials relating to specific legal topics such as class action suits. Also included are several files of speeches that Daly gave at professional meetings and community events.
